item.title: Active Recon Resources
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: Active Reconnaissance To gather intelligence by actively engaging the target. In the active reconnaissance phase, we’re planning our future phases, like exploitation, by actively collecting information on the target by enumeration, scanning, etc. Few examples: What targets were found and what ports are open?

item.title: Passive Recon Resources
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: Passive Reconnaissance To gather intelligence without actively engaging the target. In the passive recon phase, we’re planning our future steps by passively collecting information on the target by fingerprinting, using OSINT, etc. Few examples: Any email formats found? What names can we find related to the target?

item.title: DC-3 of the DC Series
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: I enjoyed DC-2’s Tom & Jerry theme! It showed us the concept of credential reuse and weak passwords, along with the misconfigurations of wordpress and SUID set binary. Anyways, now onto DC-3.2 aka DC-3! DC-3 Details Dropdown to see DC-3's quick overview DC-3 is another purposely built vulnerable lab with the intent of gaining experience in the world of penetration testing.

item.title: DC-2 of the DC Series
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: With DC-1 out of the way, let’s move onto DC-2 of the DC Series! DC-2 Details Click here to see DC-2's quick overview. Much like DC-1, DC-2 is another purposely built vulnerable lab for the purpose of gaining experience in the world of penetration testing.

item.title: DC-1 of the DC Series
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: Let’s root DC-1! Details can be found at https://www.five86.com/dc-1.html Open this to see the box's overview pulled from the above website. DC-1 is a purposely built vulnerable lab for the purpose of gaining experience in the world of penetration testing. It was designed to be a challenge for beginners, but just how easy it is will depend on your skills and knowledge, and your ability to learn.

item.title: Networking Basics
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: Basics of Networking A network is two or more hosts connected together in order to exchange data. There’s two network types: WAN (Wide Area Network) - network that connects large geographical areas. LAN (Local Area Network) - network that is confined within a WAN network.

item.title: OSI Model
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: OSI Layers & PDU OSI Model is a 7 abstract layer table that’s responsible for explaining the flow of data within a network. Experienced individuals will often call out an issue by the culprit layer number. example: “This is a level 3 issue.

item.title: Linux File Hierarchy
item.author: revsh3ll
item.description: / Root - Where it begins Linux uses a tree oriented hierarchy, meaning it starts at one point and branches outward. This starting point is the / (system root) directory. This particular hierarchy layout is based on the FHS (Filesystem Hierarchy Standard).
